description: A tropical or subtropical vine grown for its strikingly long fruit, which can reach up to 1.5 meters. The fruit is slender, often twisted or curled, with a waxy green skin that may have lighter green or white stripes.
healthBenefits: Low in calories and a good source of dietary fiber.
Provides Vitamin C, supporting the immune system.
Contains minerals like calcium and phosphorus.
Traditionally used in Ayurvedic medicine for various ailments.
cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Planting: Warm-season vine. Sow seeds directly after last frost.
2. Soil: Well-drained, fertile loamy soil rich in organic matter. pH 6.0-7.0. Full sun.
3. Support: Requires a very strong and tall trellis or arbor for the long fruits to hang and grow straight.
4. Watering: Needs regular and deep watering, especially during fruit development.
5. Harvesting: Harvest fruits when they are young and tender, typically 12-18 inches long (though some varieties grow much longer). Overmature fruits become hard and bitter.
growthDuration: 60-80 days from sowing to first harvest.
sustainabilityTips: Store snake gourd in the refrigerator for 3-5 days.
Lightly scrape or peel the skin. Remove soft pith and seeds if mature.
Commonly used in curries, stir-fries, and stews in South Asian cuisine.

staticRecipes.name: Snake Gourd Kootu (South Indian Stew)
staticRecipes.description: A flavorful South Indian stew made with snake gourd, lentils, and coconut.
ingredients: 1 medium snake gourd, scraped, seeded, and chopped
1/4 cup moong dal or toor dal, cooked
For tempering: 1 tbsp oil, 1/2 tsp mustard seeds, 1 dried red chili, few curry leaves
steps: Cook chopped snake gourd with a little water and turmeric powder until tender. Drain excess water.
Grind coconut, cumin seeds, and green chilies to a smooth paste with a little water.
Add cooked dal and ground coconut paste to the cooked snake gourd. Add salt. Mix well.
Simmer for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until flavors blend and kootu thickens slightly.
Tempering: Heat oil. Add mustard seeds; when they splutter, add dried red chili and curry leaves. Pour over the kootu. Mix and serve hot with rice.

staticRecipes.name: Stuffed Snake Gourd (Bharwa Chichinda)
staticRecipes.description: Snake gourd pieces stuffed with a spiced lentil or vegetable mixture and cooked.
ingredients: For stuffing: 1/2 cup cooked chana dal (mashed), 1 onion (finely chopped), 1 tsp ginger-garlic paste, 1/2 tsp turmeric, 1 tsp coriander powder, salt, oil
steps: Wash and lightly scrape the snake gourd. Cut into 2-3 inch long pieces. Gently scoop out the inner pith and seeds, creating hollow cylinders.
Stuffing: Heat oil, sauté onions. Add ginger-garlic paste. Add mashed dal and all spice powders. Cook until mixture is dry. Cool.
Stuff the snake gourd pieces with the prepared mixture.

Heat oil in a wide pan. Arrange stuffed snake gourd pieces. Cook on low-medium heat, covered, turning occasionally, until tender and lightly browned (about 15-20 mins). Add a splash of water if needed to prevent sticking.

staticRecipes.name: Snake Gourd Poriyal (Stir-fry)
staticRecipes.description: A simple South Indian stir-fry with snake gourd and minimal spices.
ingredients: 1 medium snake gourd, scraped, seeded, and finely chopped
steps: Heat oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds. When they splutter, add urad dal and red chilies. Sauté until dal turns golden.
Add asafoetida and chopped snake gourd. Add turmeric powder and salt.
Stir well. Cover and cook on low-medium heat for 7-10 minutes, or until snake gourd is tender, stirring occasionally.
Stir in grated coconut. Cook for another minute. Serve hot with rice and sambar/rasam.
